Award.AwardTitle: CAP: Advancing Technology and Practice for Learning Reading and Writing Skills in Secondary Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed workshop brings together researchers and educators to discuss how to advance technology and practice to better promote secondary school science literacy. There is a clear need for new directions in science literacy. Over the past decade, the National Center for Education Statistics has consistently identified poor reading and writing skills as a serious problem, one which undoubtedly contributes to low science achievement. In addition, written and oral communication skills have been identified as a significant dimension of science practice and education. Secondary school, the focus of this workshop, is a critical period when students first experience a separation between subject matter and literacy. The resulting disciplinary silos may create discontinuities in students' learning of both science content and literacy skills. It may be advantageous for instruction in science and the English language arts to be brought closer together at the secondary level, and to facilitate this through digital learning environments.

Secondary science education has benefited from a range of digital technologies, including computer supported collaborative learning systems (CSCL) and intelligent tutoring systems (ITS). The hypothesis motivating the workshop is that results from a decade of work in computer-based learning for science and inquiry can be applied to science literacy. One precondition is appropriate application of automated techniques to analyze the texts that students read and write, so as to provide students with tailored feedback in an online setting. A second precondition is to apply insights from the psychology of education on the acquisition of general literacy skills, and argumentation skills in particular, to foster evidence-based communication. The workshop includes researchers from the three critical areas of computer-based learning environments, natural language processing, and the psychology of education. It has three main goals. The first is to share results, datasets and demonstration systems in order to identify the potential for collaborations that would both deepen the analysis of existing data, and identify criteria for the collection of novel datasets that specifically address science literacy. The second workshop goal is to foster collaborations among researchers in the three disciplines, with participation from practitioners, to study the potential impact on students' learning of science literacy skills. The third workshop goal is to identify mechanisms to foster an interdisciplinary community that will continue to investigate science literacy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Capacity building project, Advancing Technology and Practice for Learning Reading and Writing Skills in Secondary Science Education, fostered new activities and discussions within an interdisciplinary academic community interested in developing educational technology to support reading and writing skills. Development of these skills takes place across at least a decade, if not longer. They are critical for learning disciplinary content, for professional success, and for a knowledgeably engaged citizenry.  The project activities brought together researchers from natural language processing, a branch of AI that studies how to process language by machine, and from psychology of education, learning design, and human-computer interaction. Four kinds of capacity-building activities were carried out: interdisciplinary workshops, academic publication, new collaborations, and engagement with funding and policy initiatives. Each had significant outcomes over the course of the project, which ran from January 1, 2015 through June 30, 2018.

Two interdisciplinary workshops were held, one at Columbia University (Multidisciplinary Advances in Reading and Writing for Science Education: MARWISE, May 7-8, 2015), and one at Penn State University (Connecting Language, Interaction and Education in Digital Environments: CLIEDE, September 26-27, 2017). The workshop formats were designed to stimulate many kinds of interaction, and included oral presentations, keynote talks, panel discussions and roundtables, poster sessions, and speed-dating collaboration events. There were twenty-­seven faculty and researchers at the first workshop, representing the psychology of education, learning design, natural language processing, automated essay assessment, and educational technology design. The second workshop had fifty-three attendees from similarly diverse disciplines, and included graduate students as well as faculty and research scientists.  Permanent websites document the two workshops, both of which helped foster the three other kinds of activities, namely publication, collaboration, and public policy input.

Plans to publish a proceedings of the first workshop evolved into a two-issue sequence of the International Journal of Artificial Intelligence in Education (IJAIED vol. 27, no. 4, 2017; vol. 28, no. 1, 2018) with five peer-reviewed journal articles in each issue.  Six of the ten papers were extended versions of work presented at the first workshop; the four others were submitted in response to an open call. The three co-PIs and an additional expert served as guest editors. Two of the co-PIs, Passonneau and Perin, were first author of articles in the special issues, which were peer reviewed by outside editors and reviewers to ensure the quality and objectivity of the publications.  Passonneau was later invited to serve on the IJAIED editorial board.  As noted below, two distinct collaborations that resulted from the first workshop led to publications at the 13thannual workshop on Innovative Use of NLP for Building Educational Applications (BEA; June, 2018).

The PIs participated in several proposal submissions to external agencies, and internal funding from Penn State University. In 2017, PI Passonneau was awarded a fellowship from Penn State’s Teaching and Learning with Technology (TLT) in 2017. The second workshop was partially supported by TLT, and by the Waterbury Chair of Secondary Education at Penn State, Prof. Richard Duschl. Co-PIs Passonneau and Muresan and an expert in educational technology from the University of Wolverhampton in the U.K. recently received an EAGER Early-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research from the National Science Foundation to investigate the potential of automated feedback for instructors who incorporate argumentative essays in their curricula. This work continues a collaboration that grew out of the first workshop, and that produced a publication on exploring how automated feedback on student summaries can help instructors of large, college-level classes in academic skills (BEA 2018). Passonneau co-authored a paper from another collaboration on educational technology that produced a novel application of machine learning to generate good distractors for multiple choice questions (BEA 2018). She served on the doctoral thesis committee of the paper’s first author.

There were two contributions to policy discussions. Passonneau was asked to participate in a meeting in May 2016, sponsored by the Organization for Economic Co­-operation and Development, to compare computer and human language skills using the Survey of Adult Skills test developed under the Programme for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC). The meeting results provided input for future educational and workforce policies. Passonneau, the co-PIs, and members of the first workshop also authored a white paper arguing for the need to stimulate new collaborations to support NLP applications of educational technology. They believe this arena will become increasingly  import.
